abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Fears of genetic discrimination in life insurance continue to deter some Australians from genetic testing. In July 2019, the life insurance industry introduced a partial, self-regulated moratorium restricting the use of genetic results in underwriting, applicable to policies up to certain limits (eg AUD$500,000 for death cover).</jats:p><jats:p>We administered an online survey to consumers who had taken, or been offered, clinical genetic testing for adult-onset conditions, to gather views and experiences about the moratorium and the use of genetic results in life insurance, including its regulation.</jats:p><jats:p>Most respondents (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 367) had undertaken a genetic test (89%), and had a positive test result (76%; <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 243/321). Almost 30% (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 94/326) reported testing after 1 July 2019. Relatively few respondents reported knowing about the moratorium (16%; <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 54/340) or that use of genetic results in life insurance underwriting is legal (17%; <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 60/348). Only 4% (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 14/350) consider this practice should be allowed. Some respondents reported ongoing difficulties accessing life insurance products, even after the moratorium. Further, discrimination concerns continue to affect some consumers’ decision-making about having clinical testing and applying for life insurance products, despite the Moratorium being in place. Most respondents (88%; <jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 298/340) support the introduction of legislation by the Australian government to regulate this issue.</jats:p><jats:p>Despite the introduction of a partial moratorium in Australia, fears of genetic discrimination persist, and continue to deter people from genetic testing. Consumers overwhelmingly consider life insurers should not be allowed to use genetic results in underwriting, and that federal legislation is required to regulate this area.</jats:p>

title: Community concerns about genetic discrimination in life insurance persist in Australia: A survey of consumers offered genetic testing
